channel.title: Painting on a canvas using reflection?
channel.description:
Would there be anyway to reflect on runescape's canvas and set it to the paintable canvas? I know we could just use BCEL to edit runescapes canvas and set it that way to a paintable canvas, but im trying to avoid using BCEL to do that type of shit.
Thanks if any of you guys can help me with this

item.title: Painting on a canvas using reflection?
item.dc:creator: @The_Flames The_Flames
item.description:
@The_Flames wrote:

dunt help him he’s tryin to CR34T HIS OWN B0T LOL!

Read full topic
item.source: Painting on a canvas using reflection?

item.title: Painting on a canvas using reflection?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

This has been done to death and I’m sure I’m repeating myself but here we go again with a reflection based canvas hack…

Set the Canvas’s peer to an instance of a light weight peer. That way it will paint on the parent’s component.
Dispose the old heavyweight peer so it doesn’t cover what you want to draw.
Create an instance of JComponent (or similar) and override the getGraphics() method in a similar way to bytecode editing bots (double buffered, etc…).
Make the client a child of the component that you just created.

There will probably be some issues with focus, mouse and keyboard but you get the idea.

Read full topic
item.source: Painting on a canvas using reflection?

item.title: Painting on a canvas using reflection?
item.dc:creator: @Nader_H.I.M Nader[H.I.M]
item.description:
@Nader_H.I.M wrote:

qauters:

getComponent(0,0).getGraphics().drawWhatEverYouWant <-- that kind of idea is the only usable for reflection. But that means it will flicker like old fashion bots.

that is what ruler loves to use in ibot Lite xD

Read full topic
item.source: Painting on a canvas using reflection?

item.title: Painting on a canvas using reflection?
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

what quaters stated would be correct but would flicker because of non-double buffer, you must create 2 buffered images and draw to one then draw rs and your buffered image onto the final buffered image for true double buffering…

Read full topic
